1. Creating the macro-structure of the dictionary

On oXygen, create a new document based upon the TEI all customisation.

  • Discovering suggestions made by the editor
  • Feeling the presence of a schema
  • Understanding what a valid document is

1.1. Importance of the metadata in <teiHeader>

  • Basic description (title, author, project) of the docuement in <titleStmt>:
    <titleStmt>  <title>Step by step introduction to the TEI dictionary chapter</title>  <author>   <persName>    <forename>Laurent</forename>    <surname>Romary</surname>   </persName>  </author> </titleStmt>
  • Publication responsability and re-use options in <publicationStmt>:
    <publicationStmt>  <authority>   <persName>    <forename>Laurent</forename>    <surname>Romary</surname>   </persName>  </authority>  <availability>   <licence target="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/">    <p>The Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported (CC BY 3.0) Licence applies to this        document.</p>   </licence>  </availability> </publicationStmt>
  • Possible source(s) in <sourceDesc>, in the case of the present script:
    <sourceDesc>  <p>Born digital TEI document</p> </sourceDesc>

1.2. Organising the dictionary as a (structured) series of entries

Using the <div> element to organise sequences of <entry> elements:

<div type="letter" n="A">  <entry>...</entry>  <entry>...</entry> </div>

1.3. Implementing the word to sense lexical organisation (aka semasiological)

To reflect the semasiological orentation, the two main elements of an <entry> are:

  • <form>, which groups together all the form related information
  • <sense>, which groups together all the semantic informaiton associated to the form
<entry xml:lang="fr">  <form>...</form>  <sense>...</sense> </entry>

<sense> can be iterated and is recursive

The xml:lang attribute can be used on <entry> to represent the object language. It can be used again for specific elements within <entry> when the working language is different.

Note: The TEI Lex 0 iniitative recommends that all sense related information be embedded in a <sense> element and not left flat within <entry>

1.4. Component of the form

<form> may contain:

  • <orth> for the orthographic form
  • <pron> for the pronunciation

Additional elements are available for syllabification, hyphenation, etc. Have a lokk at the members of the model.formPart class.

1.5. Additional grammatical information

The <gramGrp> element can be used to provide the morphosyntactic properties of the lemma.

<entry>  <form type="lemma">...</form>  <gramGrp>   <pos>n</pos>   <gen>f</gen>  </gramGrp> </entry>

The main elements that can be used here are <pos>, <gen>, <case>, <mood>, <number>, <per>, <tns> and the generic <gram> element (together with a type attribute).

1.6. Sense related information

Within the <sense> element, it is possible to gather various types of information such as usage (<usg>), definition (<def>), examples (<cit>) or etymology (<etym>).

<entry>  <form>...</form>  <sense>   <usg type="">...</usg>   <def>...</def>   <cit type="example">    <quote/>    <bibl>...</bibl>   </cit>   <etym>...</etym>  </sense> </entry>

You can rely on the TEI documentation to explore the various elements and their constructs (google search: ‘tei element sense’): <sense>

1.7. Related entries

1.7.1. the traditional way in the TEI guidelines

The <re> element embeds <entry>-like content for describing related entries:

<entry>  <form>...</form>  <sense>...</sense>  <re>   <form>...</form>   <sense>...</sense>  </re> </entry>
Note: <re> can also appear in <sense>

1.7.2. Unified use of <entry> in TEI Lex-0

<entry>  <form>...</form>  <sense>...</sense>  <entry type="relatedEntry">   <form>...</form>   <sense>...</sense>  </entry> </entry>

2. Final remarks

  • Using TEI all provides far too many elements in the schema. It is possible to create a limited customisation with a subset of TEI elements. Ask the teacher!
